title: PM makes 'downpayment' on $30 billion shipyard to build nuclear submarines
text:
P﻿rime Minister Anthony Albanese today announced a multi-billion dollar investment in an Adelaide shipyard to train workers in building AUKUS nuclear-powered submarines.

He said the $3.9 billion cash injection into the Osborne shipyard by the federal government was a "downpayment" for the facility, which will support the 10,000 skilled workers required to build the vessels.

Albanese confirmed today the total cost will be $30 billion, as forecast by the Australian Naval Infrastructure.

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese today announced a $3.9 billion cash injection into an Adelaide shipyard building nuclear submarines. (Alex Ellinghausen)

Under the AUKUS agreement, the Australian navy will acquire eight nuclear-powered (but not nuclear armed) submarines over the next decade from the United States and Britain.

The federal government says 5500 jobs will be created at the shipyard, with thousands more ﻿indirect roles stemming from the shipyard's construction programs.

"This is a driver of not just of national security and how were going to defend our nation into the future," Albanese said.

"It's also a driver of our economic prosperity, as well as making such an enormous difference to some of the apprentices that we've met here today."

Speaking alongside the prime minister, Defence Industry Minister Pat Conroy said the Adelaide shipyard would be the only in the southern hemisphere capable of constructing nuclear-powered submarines﻿.

Australia will acquire US-built Virginia-class nuclear submarines under the first stage of the AUKUS agreement. (US Dept of Defence) (US Department of Defence)

"Importantly, this will modernise Aussie manufacturing as we go through it because it's not just the 10,000 jobs here," he said.

"We've got 70 companies already going through the qualification process to win work supplying not just Australian submarines but UK and US submarines."

AUKUS was signed five years ago by the leaders of Australia, the US and UK in a move aimed at deterring China's assertiveness in the Pacific.

Doubt over the future of AUKUS emerged last January when US President Donald Trump was sworn in.

He ordered a review of the defence pact by the Pentagon, concerned it did not meet his "America first" agenda.

The agreement hung in the balance for months until the US Defence Department gave the green light in September. ﻿

Later, Trump warmly endorsed AUKUS when he hosted Albanese at the White House, saying it was "full steam ahead".

title: NSW to get an extra public holiday for the next two years
text:
NSW will have an extra public holiday on Anzac Day weekend for the next two years, Premier Chris Minns has confirmed.

Previously in the state, if Anzac Day on April 25 fell on a weekend, there would not be an official public holiday.

However, Minns announced this morning the government will implement a trial that will see the state gain a public holiday on April 27 this year and April 26 next year.

This is because Anzac Day falls on Saturday and Sunday for the next two years.

The premier insists Anzac Day itself will remain a solemn occasion. (Sam Mooy)

This is now in line with Western Australia and the ACT , which have already implemented an extra public holiday when Anzac Day falls on a weekend﻿

Minns believes the holiday will allow people to spend more time with their friends and families, while not detracting from the importance of Anzac Day itself.

"We believe that this additional public holiday was the right thing to do," he said. "This cannot detract from the overall importance of Anzac Day, I don't think it will.

Minns conceded some business owners would not agree with the decision. (Nine)

"NSW residents can be trusted with this public holiday in the fact it won't detract from the solemnity."

Minns had flagged a potential change late last month , ﻿claiming the state has less public holidays than the rest of Australia.

He conceded the decision may not be popular with business owners.

"We've also spoken with business, not all business groups are supportive of this change, and it's important that we recognise that," he said

"We know it's somewhat of an additional burden for small business in particular, but this is an important thing we need to do for the state.

"We are not dismissing that opposition but on balance we believe that this additional public holiday was the right thing to do."

READ MORE: Milo snack bars recalled over contamination alert ﻿

Vince Williams said the RSL NSW board ultimately decided to support the move, after a survey of members was split in support and opposition. (Nine)

The decision was made after discussions with RSL NSW, who ultimately endorsed the decision.

Acting President Vince Williams admitted a survey sent to members was evenly split in support and opposition for an additional public holiday, but said the RSL NSW board ultimately voted in favour of it.

"We have a very broad church, and like many volunteer organisations, we have members who are opposed to change, and it's a case of bringing them along," Williams said.

"The great concern was what if something happened to the 25th, nothing is going to happen to the 25th, the 25th will be the day where all the commemorations will take place."

title: 'Don't be the generation to stuff it up': The reality of running the family business
text:
Sam Mackaway's future has been planned for as long as he can remember.

"I always wanted my family to grow up on a farm," he says.

He's a third-generation cattle farmer in Walcha, New South Wales, and now with a young family of his own, he's realising his dream.

"The property's been in our family for 27 years. It's 2,800-and-a-bit acres and a beautiful part of the world to raise my kids," he tells ABC iview's Muster Dogs.

Sam Mackaway wouldn't want to raise his kids anywhere else. (ABC/Ambience Entertainment: Brook Rushton)

Eventually, Mackaway will inherit the family business, but it comes with conversations about succession, debt and leaving his mark.

According to the Australian Small Business and Family Enterprise Ombudsman, seven out of 10 businesses in Australia are family-owned.

While family businesses are in every industry, 25 per cent of workers are in agriculture, forestry and fishing.

Corrina Wright is the sixth generation to run her family's business, Oliver's Taranga Vineyards in McLaren Vale, South Australia, and says it's a privilege to continue the legacy.

"You're very lucky that you've landed in the spot where you are and being able to be part of such a long family lineage," she says.

"But then there's a little bit of pressure in that, because you don't want to be the generation to stuff it up."

Corrina Wright works closely with her cousins on the family business. (Supplied: Gilbert Bages)

Eyes on the future

While Mackaway always knew he wanted to settle on the farm, he had to work hard to earn his place.

"My brother and I got told when we were younger that we needed to go and do something before we came back to the farm, we needed to get a trade or go to uni or just do something, because anything that you come back with to the farm helps," he says.

"I was quite keen on becoming a sparky [electrician], so I moved away and did that. I don't use it every day, but I use it quite a lot on the farm, just being able to make stuff."

Despite the generations of knowledge passed down, Mackaway knows he needs to look to the future if he wants the business to thrive for years to come.

Modernising the family business is one way Sam Mackaway is securing the farm's future. (ABC/Ambience Entertainment: Brook Rushton)

In doing so, he's introduced modern technology into his day-to-day work.

"I'm driving around in a tractor with a GPS and auto steer, whereas Dad's driving around in a tractor just using his eyes, trying to see the lines," he says.

While his father is an expert in using machinery to move cattle, Mackaway has taken on the challenge of learning how to introduce working dogs onto the farm.

He's also introducing a data-tracking system to streamline his processes, which will enable him to track cattle weights and growth, as well as lineage and which bulls are working with which cows.

"I'm a few weeks away from releasing a farm management app. We do have a fair few headaches just tracking our cattle."

In Wright's family business, each generation has brought its own focus to the business. In her case, it was expanding from just selling grapes to starting their own brand.

Corrina Wright's business has evolved in the hands of her generation. (Supplied: Gilbert Bages)

"You've gone from a business that didn't really care about what happened at the farm gate, your grapes were gone, and you didn't need to worry about marketing or any of that sort of stuff," she says.

"Now you're running a business that can employ a whole pile of different people, not just tractor drivers, and you've got customers coming to you, and you've got marketing to do, you've got design and social media and all those sorts of things — the generational difference is huge."

Those changes took a little while to get used to.

"The pressure back in the early days was to not stuff that up and to respect the family name that was going on a wine label," Wright explains.

"Now I feel a bit more proud that our generation has been able to contribute significantly to assisting the business and strengthening it into the future as well."

Planning ahead

Every five years, Mackaway sits down with his family to discuss succession planning.

His father's own experience has influenced the handover process with his son.

"My grandfather decided that he wasn't ready to retire. He wanted to keep going for a bit longer, and Dad thought, 'I'm going to be 65 by the time you want to retire and not run [the] place how I want to run it'. So he's very aware of that in the discussion about succession planning."

But while family businesses can bring some challenges, Mackaway says having family support has offered vital help with the costs of expanding and setting up the property he owns with his wife, Laura.

"As long as we're happy to all work together, we can get that debt down a lot quicker than if Laura and I were to move away and do our own thing. That'd take us a long time."

Sam Mackaway plans to continue working with family. (ABC/Ambience Entertainment: Brook Rushton)

For Wright, she says it's been important to have advisers who are non-family members, to keep their vision on track — but she's looking forward to creating opportunities for more family members in the future.

And while past generations were limited to farming work, roles could now be anything from a graphic designer to a lawyer.

"Legacy just means we've left it in a better spot than what we received it," Wright says.

Her daughter is already working for the company one day a week.

Meanwhile, for Mackaway and prospects of a fourth generation in the business, only time will tell.

Stream the new series of Muster Dogs free on ABC iview.

title: Treacherous strait swim the latest step to ocean challenge dream
text:
Swimming in shark-infested waters across one of the most treacherous island crossings in the world is not high up on most people's holiday bucket lists.

But for Townsville woman Liz Denyer, conquering the 22-kilometre Cook Strait between New Zealand's North and South islands was a challenge worth travelling for.

"Every swim has a different story and something that you learn about yourself," she said.

The water was 14 degrees when Liz Denyer swam the Cook Strait. (Suppled: Liz Denyer)

The 51-year-old is among a small but growing number of marathon swimmers who take on open-water swims longer than 10 kilometres.

Ms Denyer said conditions for her Cook Strait crossing on February 9 were "magnificent", except for the masses of stingers.

"They got me everywhere. There was a bit of swearing going on," she said.

"I can't count, there were lots."

It took Ms Denyer eight hours and 20 minutes to swim the strait, covering 26.6 kilometres in total due to currents.

The Cook Strait is 22km at its narrowest but swimmers cover longer distances due to currents. (ABC News: Sharon Gordon)

About 30 people complete the Cook Strait crossing each year. It is one of seven open-water swims that form a marathon swimming challenge known as the Ocean Seven.

In 2023, Perth swimmer Andy Donaldson set the record for the fastest crossing in four hours and 33 minutes.

Testing her limits

Ms Denyer said the swim was about putting her body to the test, but she did not let the adrenaline stop her from appreciating her surroundings — despite the water being 14 degrees.

"I looked ahead and there was this beautiful sunrise … this is why I do marathon swimming," she said.

" The water was calm and glassy and beautiful. "

It was those positive thoughts that helped her keep swimming in a straight line for the next eight hours, she said.

Liz Denyer's father Tris and his wife Gail were part of the support crew. (Supplied: Liz Denyer)

Her support team, including her former coach as well as family and friends, accompanied Ms Denyer by boat, throwing her food every 30 minutes and providing encouragement during the entire swim.

Bitten by the bug

Although Ms Denyer lives and works as a radiation therapist in Townsville, her passion for marathon swimming was kindled far away from her tropical hometown when she joined a London swimming group in 2017.

Soon after Liz Denyer began her Cook Strait swim she encountered many bluebottle jellyfish. (Supplied: Liz Denyer)

On her first day, another member told her he had recently swum 46 kilometres around Manhattan Island, to which Ms Denyer responded: "Why would you ever want to do that?"

But it was not long before she said she was "bitten by the bug" and decided to swim 14.4 kilometres across the Gibraltar Strait later that year.

She then ticked off the 33-kilometre English Channel in 2023 and the 32.3-kilometre Catalina Channel in 2024.

After finishing the Cook Strait, Ms Denyer's eyes are set on the final three Ocean Seven swims — the North Channel between Ireland and Scotland, the Molokai'i Channel in Hawaii, and the Tsugaru Strait in Japan.

Liz Denyer works as a radiation therapist and trains before her shifts. (Supplied: Townsville Hospital and Health Service)

A growing sport

Ms Denyer is the typical demographic of a marathon swimmer, according to Marathon Swimming Australia president Christian Renford.

He said participation across Australia was growing and skewed towards people older than 35, as the sport had a low impact on the body.

Christian Renford says marathon swimming is increasing in popularity. (Supplied: Christian Renford)

"We've got people as old as 65 floating around still doing some stunning and absolutely remarkable swims," he said.

"When people get a bit more mature in age, you like to set those goals that are very much aspirational."

He said marathon swimming appealed to people because completing the swim was more important than speed.

"It's not about the time, it's about the distance," he said.

title: PM announces $3.9b 'down payment' towards $30b submarine shipyard
text:
The South Australian and federal governments have released plans worth $30 billion for a shipyard in Adelaide that will build at least eight nuclear-powered submarines under the AUKUS pact with the US and the UK.

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese announced that the Commonwealth would make a $3.9 billion "down payment" towards the work at Osborne, with the rest of funding to "flow continuously" over the rest of the shipyard's construction, due to be complete in 2040.

On top of enabling works worth $2 billion, construction has already started on a fabrication area worth $5 billion and a Skills and Training Academy worth $500 million.

The new fabrication hall for submarines will be 420 metres long — more than twice this one at the Osborne South shipyard. (ABC News: Stephen Opie)

The shipyard's developer, Australian Naval Infrastructure (ANI), a company owned by the federal government, estimated the next stage, an outfitting area, would cost $8 billion to build, while an area for consolidation, testing, launching and commission would cost more than $15 billion.

The state government estimated at least 4,000 workers would design and build the submarine construction yard, while 5,500 workers would support nuclear-powered submarine production at its peak.

The SSN-AUKUS submarines are based on the design of the British Astute-class submarine. (Supplied: British High Commission)

Long time frame for delivery

The submarines are being built as part of the $368-billion AUKUS submarine pact announced in 2021.

It replaced a deal to build French-designed submarines, also in Adelaide.

The first part of the plan is for Australia to buy between three and five nuclear-powered submarines from the US, beginning in the early 2030s, including at two second-hand Virginia-class submarines.

Five of the eight SSN-AUKUS nuclear-powered submarines are due to be delivered by the middle of the 2050s, with the final three delivered in the 2060s.

Vice Admiral Jonathan Mead from the Australian Submarine Agency points out different parts of the new shipyard. (ABC News)

Vice Admiral Jonathan Mead, the director-general of the Australian Submarine Agency, said experts from the US and the UK had been in Adelaide advising the build.

He said the manufacturing process at Osborne would be "identical" to the shipyard building submarines in the UK.

"Their facilities are 120 years old; ours will be the most modern submarine yard in the world," Vice Admiral Mead said.

AUKUS deal details The final details of Australia's first nuclear submarine fleet have been unveiled — along with the price tag.

Mr Albanese said the construction work and then the work building submarines would provide thousands of jobs into the future in Adelaide.

"If you're a 15 or 16 year old thinking about what am I going to do with my life, you can be assured that there will be well-paid, secure jobs here in Adelaide and you'll get … that satisfaction of seeing what you are creating as a product of your labour and knowing that it is very much your contribution as well to our national interest for decades ahead," Mr Albanese said.

"We do live in an uncertain world, but we can be certain of the economic benefit to the tune of $30 billion going forward here in South Australia."

Premier Peter Malinauskas talks about the planned expansion of the Osborne shipyard. (ABC News: Stephen Opie)

Much larger than frigate work

Mr Albanese met with South Australian Premier Peter Malinauskas for a media conference at the Osborne South shipyard five weeks ahead of the state election.

Mr Malinauskas said the investment at Osborne South, where six Hunter class frigates are being built, was "extraordinary" but it "pales into insignificance" compared with the work for the AUKUS submarines.

"[We're] here to announce arguably the most structurally significant contribution to our economy that we will ever see," Mr Malinauskas said.

"What has been announced today completely dwarfs some of the investments that we've seen in South Australia's recent past — that boggles the mind."

Opposition Leader Ashton Hurn pointed out the AUKUS deal was signed by the former Coalition federal government.

"I'm really hopeful that South Australian businesses can feel a part of this project," Ms Hurn said.

"It's really important that we don't just become a glorified IKEA where we're bringing in products from right across the world and just assembling them here in South Australia

"We need to be at the heart of this manufacturing opportunity, because that's what will set us up for generations to come."

title: Taylor lays battle lines on capital gains tax as deputy defends nuclear policy
text:
Deputy Liberal leader Jane Hume says Australia needs to be "open minded" on nuclear power if the country is to bring down emissions and make power cheaper.

Ms Hume, who was elected to her new position in Friday's Liberal leadership spill, wouldn't be drawn on policy specifics during an interview with the ABC's Insiders program but said nuclear power would help bring down prices over time.

"If people were open minded to the idea of lifting the moratorium on nuclear energy … well then that would add to that energy abundance that would bring prices down over time," she said.

When asked if the party had any plans beyond nuclear energy to bring emissions down, Ms Hume would not say whether there were further policy plans in development.

"I'm not announcing policy 48 hours after having been elected deputy leader of the Liberal Party before our first shadow cabinet meeting," she said.

" But what I will say is it's absolutely crazy to have an ideological approach towards energy because it's energy that drives our economy. "

In 2025, Ms Hume fought for the Liberal Party to retain a commitment to net zero emissions by 2050, which was subsequently dumped.

She would not say whether her personal view on net zero had changed since then.

"We won't be re-prosecuting that case in the party room, there is no reason why we cannot create more energy and increase supply of energy to bring those prices down."

In its latest report, the International Energy Agency found a net zero by 2050 framework was the best way to deliver cheaper household power.

Australia's national science organisation the CSIRO has also found that renewable energy supported by storage and gas was the cheapest form of new power.

Angus Taylor and Jane Hume have outlined their key priorities but haven't gone into detail about their plans. (ABC News: Ian Cutmore)

Labor's review of its 2025 election win, and the Coalition's worst-ever defeat, found the opposition's nuclear policy was a key part of its failure to win government.

"There was also strong opposition to the Coalition's nuclear energy policy with criticisms about the cost and the long delivery timelines," the review panel said.

"Voters felt that there was a lack of detail about nuclear energy, while the Coalition's flip-flop on working from home made voters question if the party was up to the job."

The Coalition is yet to release its election review, which former leader Peter Dutton has claimed is defamatory to him and his staff.

Capital gains tax clash on the horizon

Speaking at a shopping centre in Western Sydney on Sunday morning, Opposition Leader Angus Taylor and Ms Hume said the Coalition would not be backing any changes to the capital gains tax (CGT) discount for owners of investment properties.

Who is Jane Hume, the new Liberal deputy? The Victorian senator was unceremoniously turfed from Sussan Ley's ministry after being tarred personally with much of what went wrong in the Coalition's cataclysmic loss. On Friday, she ascended to the Liberal's second in command.

The federal government is considering a reduction in the tax discount ahead of the May federal budget.

Mr Taylor said the opposition would not back any changes to CGT.

"If you tax homes, you get less homes and right now we need more homes, not less," Ms Hume said.

Ms Hume told the ABC the matter had already been discussed in the party room.

"We've known this was coming from Labor, that they're reaching back into the grab bag of higher tax policies that Bill Shorten took to a previous election that he lost."

Childcare and migration on agenda

Both Mr Taylor and Ms Hume have criticised the government's plans for a universal childcare system in their first 48 hours as the party's new leadership team.

Ms Hume said families needed more choice and flexibility in who cared for their children.

"We want to make sure that we have a system that not only makes sure that families that want to return to the workplace and have their children cared for have that opportunity to do so, but they should also have a choice as to how they go about doing that," she said.

She would not say if the Coalition was considering giving families a subsidy to pay for a nanny to care for their children.

The capital gains tax discount is shaping up as a key battle between the opposition and the federal government. (AAP Image/Lukas Coch)

"It's pretty obvious, isn't it, that childcare as it is isn't working for working Australians," she said.

"It isn't working because it's costing around $16 billion a year to taxpayers at the same time we're subsidising both the workers and users of childcare, no wonder it's becoming so out of reach for every Australian."

The pair have also been heavily critical of the federal government's approach to migration, with Ms Hume calling for a "reset" on how it is managed.

"We want to see a lower number of people come to our country, but we also want to raise the standards," she said.

"Living in Australia is one of the greatest gifts that could ever be given to anybody, which is why we want to make sure that the people that come here share our belief."

She would not say why the current citizenship test, which includes questions on values, is not sufficient, describing the matter as "a policy decision for another day after I have met with the shadow cabinet".

Mr Taylor said any changes proposed by the Coalition would not be about keeping any particular religious groups out of Australia.

"The door has been open to people who do not believe in our way of life," he said.

Mr Taylor would not say how the opposition would like to see that happen.

"We will announce more detailed initiatives over time."

title: How 'mortified' Jakara Anthony went from a fall to a second gold medal
text:
How do you pick up an athlete who has had their world collapse in on itself, right in the middle of a Winter Olympic Games?

That was the dilemma facing Jakara Anthony's long-term coach Peter McNiel this week in Livigno.

Anthony, a gold medal favourite in the single moguls midweek, crashed out in the super final when it appeared the gold medal was in her grasp.

Get the latest: Winter Olympics day eight live updates: Anthony wins historic gold for Australia Stay across the highs and lows of the Games with the ABC Sport Daily podcast and ABC Sport.

The 27-year-old was understandably crushed by her mistake.

"There's been a lot of tears, a lot of conversations had," Anthony said on Saturday afternoon, after earning her golden redemption in the dual moguls.

But there was little time for Anthony to wallow. The dual moguls competition was just three days away, meaning the path ahead for the now two-time Olympic champion was clear.

"We got back out on the course, had some training and we refocused," she said.

How she was able to compartmentalise her pain has a lot to do with her coach, McNiel.

Pete McNiel has been Jakara Anthony's coach since she was 12 years old. (Supplied: OWIA/Chris Hocking)

McNiel has been Anthony's coach since she was 12 years old, so he understood how awful she felt, even if she displayed a stoic mask in public.

"Singles day was absolutely devastating," McNiel said.

Jakara Anthony's response to defeat should make us all proud Disaster stared Jakara Anthony in the face and meted out the cruellest of injustices as she missed out on a moguls medal at the 2026 Winter Olympic Games. But her response showed us the character that should make Australia proud regardless.

"She was in unbelievable form. We had great training coming in. She'd done everything she needed to do to back up her gold medal [from Beijing] and just … in the blink of an eye, skis crossed and she had to pull out of the course.

"That night was sleepless. Jak was mortified.

"We, the coaching team, had to rally to come out for the boys the next day.

"So it was really, really challenging after such an emotional day."

McNiel said the incident that saw Anthony crash out was the same mechanism that saw her crash and break her collarbone in 2024.

Jakara Anthony's final mistake could have been a lot worse. (Reuters: Hannah McKay)

Adding to the difficulty he and Anthony both faced was the fact that one of his other charges, Cooper Woods, claimed gold the day after Anthony suffered the biggest letdown of her sporting life.

Balancing those emotions took its toll.

"It's a really weird situation," McNeil said.

"You've just missed the thing that you wanted most and then the team's winning … you're devastated and you're crying, you're so happy for the team.

"It's almost more tiring because it's like this up and down, up and down — you're happy, you're sad, you're happy, you're sad. It's like you can't catch your breath.

"She was absolutely ecstatic for Cooper. As a team we all were.

"But at a certain point in time she had to, she just had to try and get some rest so she could come back out today."

That must have been easier said than done.

Woods's victory was an extraordinary high, the release of which is still being seen around Livigno as Australians bullishly celebrate their sporting triumphs in the local bars and clubs.

Balancing the joy Anthony felt for Woods and the pain she felt was a brutal endeavour.

Bouncing back from disaster took a lot out of Anthony. (Reuters: Hannah McKay)

"The emotional toll of what happened is huge," McNiel said.

"And to be able to then, in just a day or two, be able to come back and perform at the highest level of the sport when she's been so drained.

"I think it is an absolute reflection of the work she's done to be able to have that kind of resolve.

"And I think as well, the people around her, our team, the Australian team, they just have so much support for her.

"The coaches and the athletes, you know, our team is really, really strong and we work hard together and we commiserate together and we celebrate together."

Jakara Anthony's supporters know the pain she went through this week. (AP: Abbie Parr)

Anthony also credited her support network for helping her through the disappointment.

"I have so many people believing in me, helping me kind of get that belief in myself," Anthony said.

"Pete's great with that, I have my sports psychologist, Ben, and another mental kind of coach, David, who were really helpful getting through that and turning that disappointment around.

"I've got such a great support crew around me, even my family and friends, they're just proud no matter what, so that helps mentally as well.

"I'm so lucky to have so much support because that was really challenging to come back from that disappointment the other day."

So what was it McNeil did?

He just gave Anthony the tools to help herself.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

"When you have a situation like that, the athletes need to believe, and they need to know that the people around them believe in them and that they feel supported," McNiel said.

"The main thing I did was just try and pour out love and support.

"I tried to show her that Australia was pouring out love and support and was just as devastated for her and that her result is not a reflection of who she is and all the work she puts in.

"It's just a moment on a day and that we could come back out and she can show the world that she can do it.

"Often I put my hand on her heart and say, 'It's all within you and one run isn't a reflection of your ability. You've absolutely trained for so many years at such a high level, it's all inside.'

"I just constantly reassure her that that's all inside. That it's all inside her."

title: Supporting and connecting Deaf people, Olivia finds her calling more than just a job
text:
Olivia Jackson felt invisible for over ten years working in a supermarket as a Deaf woman.

But she's finally found her true calling after swapping shelf stocking for a job as a support worker helping other Deaf people to achieve their goals.

Olivia lost her hearing as a child and primarily communicates by sign language, or Auslan, which she said was not well supported in the supermarket.

Olivia Jackson chats with her co-workers. (ABC News: Keana Naughton)

"Communication's difficult, and you've really got to monitor how and manage how you communicate with people," she said.

" It never [was] really a great experience, and so you're kind of isolated and a bit lonely. "

Advocates say Deaf Australians remain under-represented in paid work, despite being well placed to help address workforce shortages in care and disability services.

The more time Olivia spends working to fix that, the less "invisible" she feels.

Finding purpose

Last year, Olivia joined the team at Deaf Connect, a national advocacy and care provider for people who are deaf, blind or hard of hearing.

As a support worker, Olivia's day is as varied as her clients' needs.

Sometimes she is assisting people with everyday skills like cooking and at other times she is helping people advocate for themselves at medical appointments.

Vinnies volunteer finds purpose after teaching Mike Trafalski has been volunteering with Vinnies Albany since he retired from teaching due to disability, finding purpose in meeting a lot of desperate people who need help.

Whatever the situation, the communication between Olivia and her clients is vital and being Deaf gives her a unique connection to their experience.

"My favourite thing is working with so many different clients," Olivia said.

"Getting them to achieve and learn new skills, and to get out and get their social and community participation, ensuring that I'm empowering them to learn."

Deaf Connect support worker manager Katrina Lancaster said having support workers with the shared experience of being deaf was valuable to their clients.

"Many of our participants have grown up with language deprivation … having no access to English or Auslan," she said.

"So having somebody to support them that can communicate in their first language and can understand their identity, really no words can describe what that brings.

"I also think that it's a role model for participants because as a Deaf person, people will say, oh, you're like me. If you can achieve your goals, I can achieve my goals as well."

Untapped resource

Nevertheless, the national unemployment rate of people who are deaf or have disabilities is almost twice as high as able-bodied people, according to the Australian Human Rights Commission.

Even in the carer space, it is an untapped resource.

The ABS reported in 2022 that nearly half of disability carers also lived with disability, but they usually fulfil an unpaid care role for family.

Olivia Jackson works as a support worker to support Deaf and hard-of-hearing clients in their first language. (ABC News: Keana Naughton)

According to Expressions Australia support worker coordinator Debbie Celenza, the value of Deaf employees is under-recognised in every sector.

"Hiring a Deaf person in any role is under-utilised," she said, "[and] it is up to government and corporations to step and embrace the untapped resources.

"Most of our staff are deaf and support people almost daily. It's not asking for a handout or a quota, it's a benefit that should be trusted to continue."

How AI revolutionises my ability to work and study AI-powered voice recognition software is helping my career as a journalist and my studies.

The organisation's CEO, Rebecca Adam, who is also deaf, said that she wants more organisations to adopt the model for employing Deaf people across a range of areas.

"[The] benefits are huge because clients see themselves and the community feels like we are representing them.

"[We've] always hired Deaf people, probably 40 per cent of staff are deaf and I feel it is important that Deaf people are represented," Ms Adam said.

A lifelong career

While Olivia might represent the employment options for thousands of Deaf Australians, it's still not an opportunity a lot of people have.

Olivia says she'll be doing the job she enjoys for a long time. (ABC News: Keana Naughton)

But to her it's more of a calling than a job.

"Don't get me wrong [I had] great experiences where I used to work, but it's the amazing experiences I have here [that] are second to none.

"I am absolutely in love with my job, and it's where I plan to stay for a very long time."

title: Premier announces extra public holiday for NSW residents
text:
Millions will be given an extra day off work this year with the NSW premier announcing another public holiday.

Chris Minns flagged last month that he was looking into giving the state another public holiday in April for Anzac Day.

Anzac Day remembrance services will be held nationwide on Saturday, April 25, but only Western Australia and the ACT observe a public holiday on Monday, April 27.

Mr Minns announced on Sunday the government would be making the Monday after Anzac Day a public holiday in 2026 and 2027 for residents in New South Wales.

"We expect big participation, major crowds, full public, civic participation in Anzac Day on the 25th of April and then following that on the Monday, we'll have an additional public holiday," Mr Minns said.

Chris Minns flagged last month that he was looking into giving the state another public holiday in April for Anzac Day. (ABC News)

Mixed reaction from business

Mr Minns acknowledged not everybody was on board with the change.

"We've also spoken with business. Not all business groups are supportive of this change [and] I think it's important that we recognise that," he said.

"We know that it's somewhat of an additional burden for small businesses in particular, but this is, we believe, an important thing to do for the state. "

Mr Minns said the trial would be implemented for the next two years and then reviewed by the government in 2032 - when Anzac Day next fell on a weekend.

He said no Anzac Day services would be impacted, although two-up would remain illegal on any other day except April 25 and Remembrance Day on November 11.

Acting President of RSL NSW, Vince Williams, said adding the public holiday did not aim to undermine the service and sacrifice of Anzacs.

"I've already had feedback, from some smaller RSL organisations that have said, that it may give them an opportunity to get together on the Monday," Mr Williams said.

"Whereas on Anzac Day, they get spread right across the state with all visiting their, association or their former unit, but not necessarily with their local colleagues or vice versa.

"They might be missing out on that because they haven't got time with their colleagues."

David Harris was hopeful the day would give people extra time to reflect on the significance of Anzac Day. (ABC News)

NSW Minister for Veterans David Harris told the ABC he hoped the move would give the community more time to reflect on the significance of the day.

"We know Anzac Day is still the most important day and we encourage people to get out to marches and events right across NSW by having the Monday as well," Mr Harris said.

"It particularly gives extra time for servicemen and women who work on Anzac Day to spend time with their families and join in their own, personal remembrance."

New South Wales has the fewest public holidays in Australia observing only 11, compared to South Australia, Western Australia, Queensland, Victoria and the ACT which have between 14 and 15.

title: ABC Radio move to FM signals the end of an era for Perth listeners
text:
With the ABC's three Perth radio stations switching from AM over to the FM band, it is the end of an era for the 94-year-old transmitter in Hamersley.

While it is a well-known landmark in Perth's northern suburbs, Trevor Kelly has had a view of the Hamersley transmitter few others have.

He started working as a radio technician for the ABC in 1959, as a trainee with the Postmaster General (PMG), which then handled all the ABC's technical broadcasting requirements.

Trevor Kelly, retired ABC radio technician. (ABC News: Pip Waller)

"We were taken out to 6WF, Hamersley — out in the sticks — and we were shown the transmitters," he said

"The ABC 6WF transmitter was one built in about 1932 by the PMG itself.

" Then we were taken out to this great big mast and asked, 'Would you like to climb it?' "

When Mr Kelly and the other trainees said yes, they were given permission but also instructions on how to do it without electrocuting themselves.

"They said, 'Just be very careful when you get on; you've got to jump on, not touch the ground and the mast at the same time, otherwise you'll be electrified,' that was the word that was used then," he said.

"So we all jumped on, and as you jumped on, there was a zip as you touched on there.

"Eleven of us managed to get up to the top, but you couldn't go right to the top because again, you got electrified there.

"Anyhow, we all got down and it was a memorable day."

The Hamersley transmitter is 94 years old. (ABC News: Pip Waller)

It has been many decades since ABC staff were allowed to risk electrocution at work, and now, the site's days providing AM broadcasting are drawing to a close.

ABC AM stations move to FM

ABC Radio Perth, NewsRadio and Radio National will all move to frequencies on the FM band on February 23.

The move will mean "many more people can tune into the station" as well as hear a clearer sound, radio futurologist James Cridland said.

Mr Cridland, who also edits a daily podcast newsletter, said he thought the switch for ABC Radio Perth from AM to FM would be really good for the ABC.

"It's really important to make sure that the primary emergency broadcaster is available in a way that people can actually pick it up, and that, for the most people, is FM radio," he said.

Perth is the first capital city in Australia to move all stations to FM, a move that matches global trends.

James Cridland says moving to FM will boost listening in cars. (Supplied)

"If you look into Europe, most of the big broadcasters have now left the AM band," he said.

"Japan is just turning off AM for one of its national broadcasters. In much of the US, they are trying, as quickly as they can, to shift over to FM."

Crucially, moving to FM will boost listening in cars, a key audience for all radio stations.

"New electric cars have no AM [receiver] in them. They're pulling AM out of some hybrid cars as well," Mr Cridland said.

"We here in Australia get the European version of cars in terms of the in-car entertainment, and AM is not a thing in most of Europe, in much of the UK, so car manufacturers have no reason really to put it into their cars anymore."

Switching towers

For BAI Communications area manager Tim Gray, who has been involved with ABC broadcasting for 40 years, it has meant preparing an FM mast at Bickley, in the Perth Hills, for the new services.

"The transmitters are all being installed, all ready to go, ready for switch on, and we've had a significant project to upgrade the antenna system and the combiner system to combine all the new frequencies into the system," Mr Gray said.

"It's quite exciting. The team have put in a lot of work."

Tim Gray says it is an exciting milestone. (ABC News: Pip Waller)

Although he admits there is a small part of him that is sad to see the ABC depart the Hamersley site.

"This tower has been very significant in broadcasting ABC Radio Perth AM. It's part of the skyline, of Perth," he said

Due to legislation that stipulates NewsRadio must broadcast parliament on AM radio, that station will be simulcast on both bands until the law can be amended.

Equipment inside the plant room at Hamersley transmission tower. (ABC News: Pip Waller)

Mr Cridland said while AM still had a crucial place in regional Australia, where it can reach vast distances and is less susceptible to interference than it is in the city, FM made much more sense in the city.

FAQs: Moving from AM to FM Will I need to buy a new radio?

"[In cities] we live in suburbs. We commute into the CBD. You don't need a large transmitter to do that," he said.

"What you need is a transmitter that people can actually pick up the signals from in their car and in their house. And more and more these days, that's FM and not AM.

"It's something that, frankly, the ABC should be doing in all of the capital cities."

ABC Radio Perth will be on 102.5 FM, Radio National to 103.3 FM and ABC NewsRadio to 104.1 FM from February 23.

title: Origin coaches hail the successful return of interstate Aussie rules
text:
Winning Victoria coach Chris Scott and his Western Australia counterpart Dean Cox have called for State of Origin to be played every year after the concept's stunning return in Perth.

A sellout crowd of 58,141 fans turned up to Perth Stadium on Saturday night to watch Victoria hold on for a hard-fought 24-point win, 18.17 (125) to 15.11 (101).

WA closed to within six points early in the final quarter following three quick goals to Jesse Hogan, but Victoria's star-studded squad was able to manage the heat and see out the win.

Carlton star taken to hospital as Victoria wins Origin Victoria holds off a spirited WA side to win the first Aussie rules State of Origin clash for 27 years, though the game is marred by a serious injury to Carlton star Jacob Weitering.

It marked the first AFL Origin match since 1999, and the resounding success of its return has already sparked calls for the concept to continue.

"I would love nothing more than to see this grow," Scott said.

"I'm obviously a huge advocate. And I think this has got the potential to be something big.

"I don't see any reason why it shouldn't be every year.

"Maybe if the player interest does wane a little bit, maybe then you think about adjusting it, but I can't imagine that being the case.

"I think it will only grow legs. I mean, as a coach, I think it's the best time now in pre-season.

"For example, our players have a practice match against Hawthorn on Monday. I know where I'd rather my players be playing."

Importantly, players from both sides went all-out in their attempt to win the game, and a number of the league's biggest stars have already signalled their desperation to represent their state next year.

Scott said WA had the "front running" to host Origin again, given the way fans in the state embraced it, but he knew there would be other states knocking down the door to take part.

"It really has got some potential," Scott said.

"If you were a South Australian-aligned player or an Allies-aligned player, you had to watch that game thinking, 'How can you leave us out of this contest?'"

Cox is equally optimistic about Origin's future.

"I think State of Origin should be every year," Cox said.

"It's for the AFL to work out who plays in that, whether it's a carnival, whether it's a standalone game.

"The WA government, WA Tourism and the WA public showed that they'll support it no matter what time of the year it comes, and they probably deserve to hold it."

Not one AFL star who was fit and eligible to play for either Victoria or Western Australia turned down the opportunity to take part.

The huge buy-in from players was arguably the biggest reason for the concept's success, and even the glut of injuries to come out of Saturday's game did not dampen the excitement.

Carlton defender Jacob Weitering was taken to hospital with possible neck, rib and shoulder damage after being crunched in a marking contest.

Adelaide recruit Callum Ah Chee, Port forward Mitch Georgiades and GWS defender Sam Taylor had their games cut short due to hamstring niggles, while Gold Coast's Brownlow medallist Matt Rowell injured a finger.

Nevertheless, Hogan said the players had embraced the concept.

"This year was a little bit of the unknown," Hogan said.

"I mean, all the players were excited for it, but we weren't really sure what to expect.

"As we were getting closer, as the teams getting announced, the excitement kind of grew.

"I think everyone that played under-age footy or wants to play for their state or watched tonight. I think this could blossom into something special.

"There's absolutely no reason why the players wouldn't want to buy into this every single year. Hopefully it's here to stay."

AAP

title: Forrest launches battery-powered trains as green deadline nears
text:
After years of delays, the rail routes of Western Australia's resource-rich Pilbara are starting to whirr with the sound of battery-electric power.

Fortescue launched two battery-electric locomotives this week, rounding out its fleet of 70 diesel-powered machines hauling precious iron-ore from pit to port.

Fortescue put its latest battery-electric locomotives on show in Port Hedland. (ABC Pilbara: Alistair Bates)

Billionaire Andrew Forrest's mining giant is the second of the region's major companies, and among its largest carbon emitters, to test the technology.

BHP began its own Pilbara trials of battery-electric trains in November.

"We'll test them with our conventional fleet and we want to understand exactly [their] performance … then we'll pull the trigger on a fully decarbonised solution for rail," said Fortescue chief executive Dino Otranto.

Rarely caught short on spectacle, the first of the blue-and-white locomotives pulled into Port Hedland's Thomas Rail Yard to rock band Wolfmother's 2005 hit, Joker & the Thief.

The locomotive's battery is the equivalent of "200 to 300 average electric vehicles" and capable of powering a refrigerator for 30 years, according to Mr Otranto. (ABC Pilbara: Alistair Bates)

The locomotives, purpose-built by Caterpillar subsidiary Progress Rail, boast what Fortescue has called the world's largest land-mobile battery, with a capacity of 14.5 megawatt-hours.

The pair will save the company 1 million litres of diesel each year, still just a fraction of the 80 million litres the company consumes annually.

"It is a large undertaking: these take probably a couple of years to manufacture, so once we pull an order, you can see it will take a couple of years to transition the entire fleet," Mr Otranto said.

The company hopes to complete the transition ahead of its "real-zero" deadline of 2030.

Fortescue back on track

The locomotives' massive battery will be charged in two ways.

The first is via Fortescue's growing renewable energy apparatus, which it says it is expanding aggressively at a rate of more than 3,000 solar panels a day.

Fortescue plans to totally electrify its transport network over the next "couple of years". (ABC Pilbara: Alistair Bates)

The second charging method is through regenerative braking, a mechanism drawing closely from the company's stalled "Infinity Train" concept.

Andrew Forrest had previously touted an in-house electric rail model, developed with Australian engineering firm Downer Group, that generated all the power it needed using the uphill-downhill dynamics of the Pilbara ranges.

The project was canned, however, in September, axing more than 100 staff.

The significance was not lost on rail operations specialist Ryan Coy, who was among the locomotive's first drivers. (ABC Pilbara: Alistair Bates)

Rio Tinto mothballs electric rail

Like its homegrown competitor, Rio Tinto has long emphasised the importance of rail to its decarbonisation efforts.

The British-Australian multinational ordered its first battery electric locomotives from American manufacturer Wabtec in 2022 and pledged to roll them out in the Pilbara in 2024.

The transport of Pilbara iron-ore spans more than 2,000 kilometres of privately owned rail. (Supplied: Rio Tinto)

The eventual replacement of more than 200 diesel locomotives was supposed to slash roughly three per cent of Rio Tinto's total emissions, although that milestone is far off.

The ABC understands Rio Tinto recently shelved its partnership with Wabtec.

"While battery locomotives represent an important area of technological development, our analysis indicates that current battery technology is not yet viable for our Pilbara rail operations," a spokesperson said in a statement.

Peter Newman was critical of Rio Tinto's reluctance to pursue battery-electric rail. (ABC News: Benjamin Gubana)

Curtin University professor of sustainability Peter Newman slammed the company's "backwards step".

"They will regret not going down this net-zero path quickly because it is going to be cheaper, better for their markets, better for their company in general," he said.

Race to decarbonise

The Pilbara region produces about 40 per cent of WA's carbon emissions, despite being home to just 2 per cent of its population.

It is overwhelmingly produced by the iron-ore industry, from which a quarter of the state's annual revenue flows.

Fortescue has developed rows of BYD battery banks to store solar energy collected near its Iron Bridge mine. (ABC Pilbara: Alistair Bates)

BHP vice-president of operational decarbonisation Daniel Heal said the company's own Wabtec locomotive prototypes were undergoing "no-load commissioning".

"The intent is that we'll have those pulling iron ore in the Pilbara in the coming months," he said.

" Diesel, for us, contributes about two-thirds of our emissions today. "

BHP said its Wabtec locomotives were still a long way from implementation at scale. (Supplied: BHP)

Mr Heal could not point to a fixed timeline for the trials and stood by the miner's decision to slash its decarbonisation budget.

"We've moved that funding to the 2030s … the engineering challenges mean it's going to take probably a bit longer than people anticipated."

Fortescue's solar farm near the Iron Bridge mine. (Supplied: Fortescue)

Dr Newman said Fortescue was not without criticism, accusing the company of neglecting "straightforward, practical solutions" for "wasteful" projects it had since abandoned.

The company has walked away from a host of green hydrogen projects in recent years, including a multi-billion-dollar hydrogen electrolyser plant once spruiked to be a global pioneer.

Mr Otranto defended Fortescue's record with the new locomotive looming behind him.

"We have not slowed down with hydrogen whatsoever. In fact, our green iron plant at Christmas Creek in the Pilbara will be using Australia's largest liquefied hydrogen plant to produce green metal," he said.

Fortescue is resolute that it will reach its goal of zero carbon emissions with zero offsets by the end of the decade.

title: Quick hits: Olympic village out of condoms, cheat claims rock curling
text:
Protective gear is in short supply in Italy as tensions boil over in the curling and a Norwegian-born Brazilian makes history.

Here are the quick hits from the Winter Olympics.

1. Olympic Village in crisis as condoms run out

Protective gear is in short supply at the Winter Games. (Getty Images: Jared C. Tilton)

Both on and off the ice, protective gear is in hot demand at the Milano Cortina Winter Games.

And some of it is in perilously short supply, according to Italian outlet La Stampa.

The newspaper has reported that the complimentary condom allowance at the Olympic Village has been exhausted in record time.

"The supplies ran out in just three days," an anonymous athlete said.

" They promised us more will arrive, but who knows when. "

Reportedly, just 10,000 condoms were made available at the start of the Games, compared with the 300,000 that were provided at the Summer Games in 2024 (although there were over three times as many athletes in Paris as there are currently in Italy).

Before the supply ran dry, Spanish athlete Olivia Smart took to Instagram to provide proof of the Lombardy-branded prophylactics.

The video, as seen below, was also shared by President of Lombardy, Attilio Fontana.

Loading Instagram content

2. Norwegian-born Brazilian claims South America's first-ever medal

After 102 years, South America finally has its first Winter Olympic medal.

Brazilian skier Lucas Pinheiro Braathen was the athlete to break the continent's duck, emphatically claiming gold in the men's giant slalom, finishing almost a minute ahead of 2022 champion Marco Odermatt.

But Pinheiro Braathen wasn't always a Brazilian skier. Up until a shock retirement in 2023, he represented Norway, the country of his birth.

However, five months after hanging up the skis, Pinheiro Braathen was back on the international circuit, but this time in the colours of Brazil, for whom he is eligible through his mother.

Two years later, Pinheiro Braathen is a history maker, and in no doubt about his decision.

Upon winning gold, he collapsed onto the snow, overcome with the enormity of his achievement.

"I've tried over and over again to put words to what I'm feeling, but it's simply impossible," Pinhero Braathan said.

"If there is anything that I hope I can be as a source of inspiration today, it's that you dare to be who you are."

3. Cheating curling chaos

Curling's international governing body says it will have officials monitoring for rule violations during the rest of the competition after Sweden's men's team accused Canada of cheating in a tense round-robin game.

Tensions boiled over when Brad Jacobs's Canada beat Sweden 8-6, with Niklas Edin's rink alleging their opponents were double touching the stone during the contest.

Canada was embroiled in curling controversy in Italy. (Getty Images: Andrew Milligan/PA Images)

World Curling has introduced electronic handles on stones at the Games, which flash red if players are still making contact with the stone beyond the hog line — the point where curlers must let go during delivery.

However, ‌the sensor for detecting violations is in the handle, with Sweden claiming Canada's players were touching the granite, where there are no sensors.

"It is not possible for World Curling to have game umpires positioned to observe all hog lines for every stone delivery," World Curling said in ‌a statement.

"However, beginning with the Saturday afternoon session, two officials will move between all four sheets and observe deliveries."

Get the latest: Winter Olympics day eight live updates: Anthony wins historic gold for Australia Stay across the highs and lows of the Games with the ABC Sport Daily podcast and ABC Sport.

After Sweden ‌and Canada asked officials to keep an eye on their opponents' deliveries early on, there was a heated exchange between the teams' thirds Marc Kennedy and Oskar Eriksson towards the end of the game.

Eriksson told Kennedy he would show him a video replay of him touching the stone repeatedly.

The Canadian responded with an expletive.

4. Skier breaks ski, still claims silver

Ebba Andersson was forced to race with one ski for 30 frantic seconds. (Getty Images: Alex Slitz)

Sweden was favourite heading into the women's 4x7.5-kilometre team relay, but its hopes of finishing atop the podium were all but dashed in the second leg.

Ebba Andersson crashed forward dramatically, not only losing ground on her opponents but breaking a ski in the process.

Rising from the snow, she was forced to hobble along with just one blade for 30 bizarre, painstaking seconds.

And the comedy of errors was only added to when a member of the support team, racing to restore Andersson's symmetry, slipped in their haste.

However, Sweden wasn't done there, responding impressively to claim silver.

5. More injury pain for Australia

Laura Peel officially withdrew from the Games on day eight. (AAP Image: Dan Himbrechts)

On day eight, Milano Cortina officially became Australia's most successful Games in history.

But amid the ecstasy of Jakara Anthony's history-making dual moguls gold was another little bit of agony for an already injury-ravaged Australian team.

Australian aerial skier Laura Peel was the latest athlete to be forced to withdraw from the Games, following an injury sustained at a training camp in Switzerland earlier this month.

Nursing a torn ACL, the two-time world champion and genuine medal contender was always facing an uphill battle to prove her fitness, but she was understandably "heartbroken" nonetheless.

Peel is the fourth Australian to have their Olympic dreams dashed by injury in recent days, with Cam Bolton fracturing his neck in training, Misaki Vaughan being concussed during her preparations and Daisy Thomas belatedly succumbing to a reinflammation of her ACL injury.

ABC/Reuters

title: 'We see plans emptied in weeks': Alarm over remote NDIS recruitment tactics
text:
People with disabilities in remote Northern Territory communities are being targeted by unscrupulous NDIS providers using high-pressure sales tactics and inducements including cash, cigarettes and alcohol, an ABC investigation can reveal.

Disability workers say they are witnessing aggressive recruitment of clients and the rapid draining of funds from plans, amid a rush of new providers into the outback NT market.

The ABC has obtained a dossier of complaints, compiled into a report, that has been sent to the NDIS Quality and Safeguards Commission, which is responsible for regulating providers.

The document paints a troubling picture of predatory behaviour by companies looking to exploit "high value" customers in remote Aboriginal communities in the NT, where plans can be larger to account for the expense of remote service delivery.

"People are being promised phones or KFC to change providers," one anonymous NT disability advocate said.

" It's happening every week. "

Now, some Territorians living with disability are speaking out about their experiences.

Do you know more? Contact reporter James Elton on elton.james@abc.net.au, or, if you require more secure communication, on jameseltonabc@protonmail.com

'I didn't know what it was for'

Jalkie Rickson said she was sitting in a front yard in her small Top End community of Wugularr, about 400 kilometres south-east of Darwin, last year, when she was approached by a woman she'd never met, who wanted her to sign an NDIS service agreement.

Jalkie Rickson says the unknown woman approached her and pushed her to sign an NDIS service agreement (ABC News: James Elton)

Ms Rickson, who has limited mobility and uses a walker, was already receiving NDIS support through other carers.

She said she did not understand the document being presented to her, and the woman did not explain it.

"She told me to sign up. But I didn't know what it was for," Ms Rickson said.

" She just told me to sign. She wasn't explaining why … she never said: 'This is what you're signing for'. "

Despite her reservations, Ms Rickson eventually signed the form.

Jalkie Rickson's disabilities mean she can't walk very far without help. (ABC News: James Elton)

The provider later returned, Ms Rickson said, and drove her in a car to another town about one hour away.

Ms Rickson can't recall exactly when, but at some stage she alleges the carer also gave her a pouch of tobacco.

Ms Rickson says she did not understand at the time that the carer was about to place her in a live-in home in the town.

'In there, there's not any hope'

Once there, she quickly became concerned about the level of care in the home.

"[The carer] just left me — left us there and took off to go wherever she want, you know?," she said.

Ms Rickson's disabilities mean she cannot walk very far without support.

She said the carer did not facilitate any trips outside, making her feel like she was being treated like a "slave" or a "hostage".

"In there, there's not any hope. You cannot go out. Just gotta sit. Watch TV. Make tea," she said.

Jalkie Rickson says making tea was one of the few things she was able to do inside the live-in home. (ABC News: James Elton)

After a short while living in the home — Ms Rickson estimates between four days and a week — she made a call and arranged for someone to come and pick her up.

Ms Rickson then phoned the carer to cancel her service agreement. The carer told Ms Rickson she would visit her again in Wugularr soon to collect $140 to pay her back "for the smokes".

"Some people, they get greedy," Ms Rickson said. "They love the money, most."

Bernadette Wallace, an NDIS support coordinator who had been managing Ms Rickson's care up to that point, said the experience was a "total rug pull" for Ms Rickson's existing providers.

Bernadette Wallace found herself cut off from accessing Jalkie Rickson's online NDIS portal. (ABC News: James Elton)

She found herself cut off from accessing Ms Rickson's online NDIS portal.

"I didn't even know where to send anything, to be able to have a handover so then they could be aware of what's already in place," Ms Wallace said.

After meetings with NDIS representatives, Ms Rickson was able to return to Ms Wallace and her other previous providers.

An associate of the carer who picked up Ms Rickson told the ABC the matter was under investigation by the NDIS regulator, so the company was unable to comment.

"We have fully cooperated with the Commission and provided all requested documentation," the associate said.

"We categorically deny the allegations of high-pressure sales tactics, inducements, or any breach of the NDIS Code of Conduct."

Access to alcohol

In the Northern Territory, most Indigenous communities are dry. Buying alcohol on behalf of others is a serious offence.

But there are reports that some NDIS providers are facilitating access to alcohol to win over and retain customers in the bush.

Floyd Rose, a Warlpiri man from the dry community of Lajamanu on the northern edge of the desert, says last year he witnessed an NDIS provider for his late disabled mother providing alcohol to her and members of his extended family.

Floyd Rose says he saw an NDIS provider facilitating access to alcohol for his mother and members of his family. (ABC News: Jayden O'Neill)

"His role [was] to look after her, bring her up, take some family out," Mr Rose said.

"Most of the time he [goes to] Lajamanu, go round there, take some people — but not safe I think, with grog."

"Why this fella buying grog every day for this mob?"

Mr Rose said he felt the man did not appear to have the right motivations for an NDIS provider.

Floyd Rose says the man providing alcohol to community members doesn't sit right with him. (ABC News: Jayden O'Neill)

The ABC has seen two invoices texted to Mr Rose's mother by two separate providers in February 2025.

The first was for $10,494 for five days of care from February 3 to February 7, while a second was for $5,659 for a single day of care on February 18.

Multiple disability workers have told the ABC those amounts could only be justified by intensive, one-on-one care, and even then they would be a stretch.

One of the providers that billed Mr Rose's mother told the ABC while they would not comment on the individual case, they specialised in high-intensity respite care that could attract high rates.

Floyd Rose is from the dry community of Lajamanu. (ABC News: Jayden O'Neill)

Gifts a widespread practice

Ms Wallace, who has worked as a support coordinator for clients in remote NT communities for the past nine years, said the use of gifts to recruit people to sign with NDIS providers was becoming a familiar story.

"The participants that I'm looking after, they've directly admitted to receiving tobacco, receiving free rides to places, receiving alcohol, [and being] induced by actual cash payments," she said.

"That's obviously to cajole them into having them as a provider."

Bernadette Wallace says NDIS providers targeting vulnerable remote participants with gifts is a growing problem. (ABC News: James Elton)

A dossier of complaints, which does not include Ms Rickson or Mr Rose's experiences, has been compiled by disability advocates and the Darwin Community Legal Service (DCLS).

The report also draws on conversations with legitimate providers and disability advocates working across the territory.

"Participants are offered food, cash, phones, gaming consoles, furniture or vouchers to switch providers or sign up for the NDIS," the document reads.

" These inducements have high appeal to people living in poverty who may have low English language or literacy skills and can't understand the consequences of the 'deal'. "

The report, compiled by disability advocates and the DCLS, outlines the widespread use of inducements and draining of NDIS plans in the remote NT. (ABC News: Marcus Kennedy)

As well as the Commission, the document has also been sent to federal NDIS Minister Jenny McAllister.

A spokesperson for the minister said Ms McAllister was "very aware" of the issues with the NDIS in the territory and had asked for "further advice from agencies" on how to address them.

Cash for introductions

Isaac Dai, a Torres Strait Islander man who married a desert woman from Lajamanu, says he and his brother were last year approached by a provider and offered $200 cash payments each in exchange for introductions to disabled people in the community.

Isaac Dai (right) says he was offered cash for introductions to disabled people in the remote community of Lajamanu. (ABC News: James Elton)

Lajamanu is extremely remote, located more than 600 kilometres away from Katherine, the nearest regional centre.

Mr Dai said the pair agreed and introduced the woman to two disabled residents.

"She told us 'I'll come back and pay you $200 dollars each'," Mr Dai said.

"But she didn't … we didn't see her from then."

"Didn't pay us. She just signed up the two person and gone."

Isaac Dai (left) says he feels the provider was only really interested in getting signatures. (ABC News: James Elton)

Mr Dai said the woman made commitments to return and assist disabled residents with cleaning their houses. But he said he was sceptical that the work would actually be done.

"This is a robbery going on. This is playing games. She just wants people's signatures, that's all," Mr Dai said.

Plans being 'drained'

Once an NDIS agreement is signed, it means companies can start invoicing for services and drawing down funds from a participant's plan.

But the report by the NT disability advocates found some providers operating in remote communities were signing up clients and then burning through funds much too quickly, by invoicing for far more care hours than their plans could support — a tactic known as "overservicing".

In some cases, the hours of care billed may not even have happened.

The NDIS is designed to give people living with disabilities access to choice and control, including by making it easy for them to change carers. (ABC News: James Elton)

"Once participants are signed up, their plans are drained of funds, the support they were promised never materialises, and they are left isolated and uncared for," the report reads.

An anonymous Tennant Creek service provider said they had seen plans that "should last a year" being "drained in two months".

"Then people have nothing left and no way to pay for help," the provider said.

An anonymous Darwin disability advocate told a similar story.

"We see plans emptied in weeks," they said.

Ms Bowker said there was a "glut of service providers clamouring to get these clients".

"I think these dodgy providers see these participants as cash cows," she said.

Against the code

The use of gifts like cigarettes, alcohol and cash is against the NDIS Code of Conduct, but falls in a legal grey area.

The Code says these methods are unethical and dishonest, but "not necessarily unlawful".

New NDIS provider rules confirmed in major shake-up The government confirms two categories of NDIS providers will be subject to mandatory registration from July 2026.

Gareth Trew, a support coordinator for well-respected Katherine service provider Step Out, said there were "absolutely no circumstances" where it was okay to use inducements.

Mr Trew said many participants were already very vulnerable to being tricked into signing agreements they didn't understand, due to factors like poor literacy or intellectual disabilities.

"Predatory providers who spot that? Absolutely, there's huge scope for them to take people's money," Mr Trew said.

Rachael Bowker, the chief executive of DCLS, said providers were offering items that could be "extremely expensive and hard to get hold of" in remote communities.

"At that very moment, sure, why wouldn't you take a phone or alcohol or cigarettes?," she said.

Rachael Bowker is concerned vulnerable people in remote communities are being taken advantage of. (ABC News: Marcus Kennedy)

Claims of ineffective complaints process

Advocates and providers across the NT said they were losing faith in the NDIS complaints process.

The NDIS Quality and Safeguards Commission "rarely follows up on serious complaints", according to the report.

"It's quite concerning that these providers, who are repeat offenders, continue to operate without any sanction at all," said Scott Richardson, a disability advocate based in Alice Springs.

Scott Richardson wants more to be done to deter providers from preying on vulnerable Territorians. (ABC News: Marcus Kennedy)

Last year, the NDIS Quality and Safeguards Commission received 409 complaints in the Northern Territory. But it has confirmed roughly half of those have yet to be "processed".

Families at breaking point ahead of defining year for NDIS Families frayed by NDIS cuts are bracing for even more change ahead of a year that's set to reshape the scheme into something more sustainable, write Nas Campanella and Evan Young.

The online register of banning orders shows there are only a handful of people who have been banned from operating under the scheme in the NT, in a market with more than 2,400 active providers.

The Commission told the ABC it could not comment on individual complaints, but said it was increasing its enforcement activities in the territory.

A spokesperson said its investigators had been to Tennant Creek and Alice Springs in December, carrying out dozens of site visits and executing warrants in response to complaints about providers in the region.

Calls for tougher enforcement, cooling off periods

The disability advocates said an independent investigative body for the territory should be set up if "inaction" by the regulator continued.

The report also argued tactics like inducements should be made "reportable incidents" under the NDIS Act, and for the introduction of a "cooling off period" for people switching providers.

The National Disability Insurance Agency, which is responsible for implementing the NDIS, said it had zero tolerance for providers offering incentives or referral payments.

The spokesperson said their own investigations had found a "strong link" between such practices and fraud.

They said the agency was aware of "challenges in the NT market" and was in the middle of a review of "cross agency intelligence" including tip-offs.
